messageBody:
> Additionally, the dynamics of the two groups are quite different. The
> Read Alphabet group is frequently comatose with many lurkers. (I would
> like to change that) On the other hand, the Shaw Alphabet group loves
> to discuss minutiae at length. Of course, thatï¿½s just my humble
> opinion. :-)

I am glad to hear thatI am not the only lurker. I'd love to spend some mor=
e time on my 'qs
projects' but alas, there is work. I also lurk on the shavian list, and oc=
casionally get some
insight into the pronunciation differences they hilite, but I agree is is u=
sually a bit
nitpicking for me to join in. If there is ever actually a shift towards sh=
avian or the read
alphabet in wide usage, I suspect spelling will standardize eventually on i=
ts own.

Actually, the thing I'd really like to see done with the Read Alphabet is g=
etting it into
Unicode. I looked into it a bit some time back, but the application proced=
ures were murky
to me. I took the first step, and created a chart of characters which I th=
ink would cover QS
quite well (uploaded in files, and updated recently to fix some errors). T=
hat is just a small
step, though, and the application to the Unicode registry is really the mos=
t important step.

One thing that needs to get sorted out before that happens is the fact that=
my chart
includes characters which don't actually exist in any current Read Alphabet=
font, e.g., the
forward-connecting MAY character, top and bottom steps, and some differentl=
y-sized
punctuation which (I think) matches the flow of QS better.

What I did NOT include are the ligatures, which are included in the Shavian=
Unicode
mapping. My reading of the Unicode guidelines led me to believe that such =
ligatures are
meant to be rendered on the fly, not encoded into the text. (It would like=
ly affect sorting,
and searching for text in a system.) Probably that is true for the differe=
nt forms of the
characters which I added, such that there is no reason to include the half-=
characters or
forward-baseline-connecting versions of characters (MAY, THEY, UTTER, NO) i=
n the
proposal. (They can still be submitted as examples of the glyph, just not =
the 'standard'
form of it.) I would love to hear comments on this.

Why Unicode? Well, for one, messages could be posted which freely mix quic=
kscript and
latin characters. I know that quickscript was originally promoted by Read =
as being much
faster to write, but with typing that is not so much of a problem (getting =
a decent QS
typing layout is also a project I spent a little time on). But the more ac=
curate sound
mapping and the economy of space still make it attractive even in printed "=
Junior" form. I
suspect that fonts which try _less_ to reproduce the handwritten form, and =
preserve a
standard space between characters (as in most printed text) would make on-s=
creen
quickscript even more readable.

My contract is up in a few weeks, and I will thereafter be traveling: a goo=
d time for side
projects such as this. I taught myself the Read Alphabet originally on a t=
rain from
Nanning, Guangxi to Kunming in Yunnan. It is easier than Chinese... but we=
've got a long
way to go before there are as many people who can read it.

oliver
